Award.AwardTitle: Arctic Observing Networks: Collaborative Research: Sustaining and amplifying the ITEX AON through automation and increased interdisciplinarity of observations
Award.AbstractNarration: The International Tundra Experiment (ITEX) was chartered in 1990 to test the effects of increased temperature on tundra plant phenology, growth, species composition and ecosystem function. Since 2007, the ITEX-Arctic Observatory Network (ITEX-AON) has continued and expanded on the ITEX program across a latitudinal transect of five sites in Alaska and Greenland, collecting core ITEX data specifically designed to address the current needs outlined in the Study of Environmental Arctic Change (SEARCH) Implementation Report. The goal of this effort is to maintain the continuity of the temporally-critical datasets of the ITEX-AON in Alaska and Greenland. Core datasets include the long-term manual observations of phenology, vegetation structure and composition, ecosystem function, and surface properties on the long-term ITEX control and experimental warming plots, repeat measurement of the vegetation plots on the 1km2 ARCSS grids, and a multifactor warming-moisture experiment in Greenland. The simultaneous measurement of multiple surface properties at the small scale has allowed detection of relationships not previously recognized, e.g., in moss-dominated areas of the intensive transects, higher albedo is linked to higher temperatures. Continuation of these measurements is imperative because increasing evidence points towards the critical importance of carry-over effects of the previous growing seasons on current and future responses and the inherent variability in the system precluded determination of the system response on the basis of a few years. Data from this project are freely available on the ACADIS website. The project will continue extensive outreach activities established in the initial phase, including strong relationships between the Fairchild Tropical Botanic Garden (FTBG) and the GVSU Regional Math and Science Center and school systems in Miami, Anchorage, Grand Rapids, and El Paso.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported continuation of long-term measurements of plant phenology, vegetation, and ecosystem properties of wet/moist and dry tundra at four tundra sites along a latitudinal/climate gradient in northern Alaska. These sites range from Barrow at the northernmost point in Alaska to Toolik Lake in the foothills of the Brooks Range and provide a natural experiment on effects of temperature and moisture on tundra responses to changing climate. Among the primary findings of the project are that the plants that currently make up the tundra vegetation are relatively rigid in their timing of growth patterns and may not be able to take advantage of the longer growing seasons in the Arctic as the climate warms.  Plants that initiate their growth early tend to senesce early, implying that they generally have fixed growth-period lengths, or that resources other than carbon (metabolic energy) gained during photosynthesis are limiting their growth.  That is, the capture of carbon is not the primary determinant of seasonal growing period because if it was, they would continue to grow longer.

The project has also shown that vegetation along the latitudinal gradient is changing rapidly with plants becoming taller and shrubs increasing in stature and abundance.  This project continued development of an automated mobile instrumented sensor platform that assesses tundra ecosystem developmental and physiological status using high resolution, ground-based remote sensing, a “tricoder” for the ecosystem that repeatedly and precisely measures the same transect at daily intervals over the short arctic growing season (Fig 1).  The daily operation of these systems at each of our four sites has provided data that can be used to examine responses at the daily time step.  The growing season in the arctic is very short, 3 months or less, and visitors often comment that it seems like it is either getting greener or browner every day, depending on the season.  With our system we have documented those changes and how they differ for different tundra ecosystems (wet or dry) and for different climate regimes (cold coastal marine to continental interior). Our data clearly show that northern cold sites have lower peak greenness that occurs earlier during the growing season and changes less in response to warm temperatures compared to more southerly warmer sites.

 

The project has repeated confirmed a finding we originally found in 2010 that the standard albedo (% reflectance of solar radiation) temperature relationship does not hold at the small scale (plot level, ~ 1m2 in moist tundra. Instead of being cooler when it is highly reflective, tundra surfaces can be warmer, and when they are more absorptive, they can be cooler. The standard idea is that reflective surfaces (e.g., white) will be cooler than absorptive, darker surfaces. We believe the explanation lies in the role of moss in the understory. Moss become more reflective when they dry out, but because they are dry, they are not evaporatively cooling, whereas moss when they are wet are more absorptive, but evaporatively cooling. Following up on that work we have demonstrated very strong effects of drying on moss reflectance, which led to further research on the effect of moss water content on normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI), a standard satellite measure that is a surrogate of plant green biomass.  We have shown that NDVI is strongly, but not linearly, sensitive to moss water content.  That means that satellite estimates of green biomass in ecosystems where moss is an important component are subject to almost daily changes as a result of drying and wetting of moss. Furthermore, we have shown that moss photosynthesis changes with water content (a well known response), but not in the same way that NDVI changes.

 

This project has had an important impact on project personnel.  Both postdocs in the project received training in many aspects of arctic ecology, remote sensing, ecophysiology, and statistical analysis, with many opportunities to mentor and interact with undergraduate and graduate students. The undergraduates on this project have also benefitted greatly. One is in a Ph.D. program in ecology, another is employed full time in a medical office, another is fuly employed as a research associate, and the latest is considering graduate school.  All of them had eye opening if not life changing experiences that have greatly increased their opportunities and networking.  Members of this project's team have also interacted with the science programs for K-12 students through the Miami Dade Science Fair, the Fairchild Challenge, and the Barrow Science Days.
